abstract.para: This document explains the content of the MMC-Pulse2 Inventory plugin configuration file

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The « Inventory » plugin is the MMC-Pulse2 plugin in charge displaying the content of the inventory database, and providing facilities for dynamic group creation.
The plugin configuration file is /etc/mmc/plugins/inventory.ini.

Like all MMC related configuration file, its file format is INI style. The file is made of sections, each one starting with a « [sectionname] » header. In each section options can be defined like this: « option = value ».

For example: [section1] option1 = 1 option2 = 2
[section2] option1 = foo option2 = plop

section.title: Configuration file sections
section.para: For now five sections are available in this configuration file:

row.entry: Select which columns are only shown in expert mode
Select which columns can be graphed
Describe which part of the inventory is going to be queryable for the dyngroup plugin
Define the rules of provisioning of users from the inventory

section.title: « main » section
section.para: This section is used to give directives to the MMC agent.

row.entry: Allows to exclude softwares in the inventory software views according to their names, using a SQL expression. For example: %KB% allows to filter all softwares containing KB in their name. Multiple filters can be set using commas.

section.para: The separator to use between two entries is ||
List is a list of Table/Column that can be queryed as it.

Double is composed like that : NAME::Table1/Column1##Table2/Column2, knowing that name MUST start by the mysql table name plus the char '/'. It's generaly used for having a AND on the same entry in a table (all machines having the software X and the version Y is not the same as all machines having the software X at the version Y)

Halfstatic is a list of Table/Column1/name complement::Column2##Value2, where the choices are on the column Column1 in the table Table where Column2 == Value2. The name complement is just to display purpose.

section.title: provisioning_inventory
section.para: This section defines some configuration directives for user provisioning with the inventory database. It allows to set access rights for users to the entities of the inventory database.
To enable the inventory provisioning system, you have to set this in /etc/mmc/plugins/base.ini:
section.screen: [provisioning] method = inventory # Multiple provisining method can be used, for example: # method = externalldap inventory

row.entry: space-separated list of login that won't be provisioned by this provisioner.
LDAP user attribute that is used to get the user profile
Space-separated list of entities assigned to the user profile "x". See the example below for more information

section.para: If the entity does not exist, it is created automatically in the database, as a child of the root entity (the root entity always exists).
For example:
section.screen: [provisioning_inventory] exclude = root profile_attr = pulse2profile profile_entity_admin = . profile_entity_agent = entityA entityB profile_entity_tech = %pulse2entity% profile_entity_manager = plugin:network_to_entity profile_entity_none = profile_entity_default = entityA profile_entity_ = entityA
section.para: In this example, the root user is never provisioned. The LDAP attribute used to get the user profile is called "pulse2profile".
The users with the "admin" profile are linked to the root entity, which is represented by the dot character. These users have access the root entity and all its sub-entities.
The users with the "agent" profile are linked to both entities "entityA" and "entityB" character. These users have access to entities "entityA" and "entityB", and all their sub-entities.
The users with the "tech" profile are linked to entities defined in the "pulse2entity" LDAP attribute values of these users.
The users with the "manager" profile are linked to entities computed by the "network_to_entity" provisioning plugin. See the next sub-section for more informations.
The users with the "none" profile are linked to no entity.
The users with none of the profiles described in the configuration file are set to the "default" profile (be carefull, default is now a keyword).
The users with no profile (the pulse2profile field is empty or don't exist) are set to profile_entity_ .
If profile_entity_ is not set, a user that doesn't have any profile (for example the pulse2profile attribute of her/his entry is empty), or that has an undefined profile, will be linked to no entity.

section.title: "network_to_entity" provisioning plugin
section.para: This plugin for the inventory provisioning system allows to link users to entities according to their IP when connecting to the MMC web interface.

The IP address of the user is determined by the Apache server running the MMC web interface thanks to the remote address of the HTTP connection. Then this IP address is forwarded to the MMC agent when authenticating and provisioning the user.
The IP address to entities mapping is done thanks to a rules file, similar to the one used by the inventory server to affect a computer inventory to an entity.
The rules file must be called /etc/mmc/plugins/provisioning-inventory. There is now to specify an alternate rules file.
Here is an example of rules file:
section.screen: entityA ip match ^192\.168\.1\..*$ entityB,entityC ip match ^192\.168\.0\.19$ . ip match ^.*$
section.para: Each line of the rules file is processing starting from the top of the file, until one rule is valid. The user IP address is matched against a regular expression. If no rule match, the user is linked to no entity.
The first line links users connecting from the 192.168.1.0/24 to the entity called "entityA".
The second line links users connecting from the IP address 192.168.0.19 to the entities called "entityB" and "entityC".
The third line is a kind of catch-all rule.
